codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_PresentationFormCode"                                                codeListValue="SDE RASTER DIGITAL DATA">SDE RASTER DIGITAL DATA</gmd:CI_PresentationFormCode>                </gmd:presentationForm>             </gmd:CI_Citation>          </gmd:citation>          <gmd:abstract>             <gco:CharacterString>Data available online at http://www.geostor.arkansas.gov This Geographic Information System dataset may be described as the 2004 LIDAR-based Digital Elevation Model (DEM) for Benton and Washington Counties in Arkansas. Vertical units are in Feet. This raster (25ft resolution) Digital Elevation Model (DEM) was generated using a bare earth point cloud obtained from Landair Mapping, Inc as part of the August 2004 LIDAR acquisition (Washington & Benton Counties, AR) coordinated by John McLarty, Elizabeth Bowen, Brian Culpepper, and Dr. Jack Cothren of the Northwest Arkansas Imagery Task Force. This collaborative project was made possible due the financial support provided by the numerous State, Federal, local government, and private sector entities who actively participated in the Northwest Arkansas Imagery Task Force meetings hosted by the NWARPC during 2004. Users of these data owe a special thanks to John McLarty (NWARPC) and Elizabeth Bowen (Benton County GIS Coordinator) for their superior leadership during this effort. Funding to support the distribution of this data via Arkansas' GeoStor was made possible by Mullins Library at the University of Arkansas, Fayetteville</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:abstract>          <gmd:purpose>             <gco:CharacterString>The source data for this DEM was a LIDAR derived bare earth model that was originally created to support the ortho-rectification processing of the 12-inch resolution, true color aerial photography collected and scanned by the Arkansas Highway and Transportation Department (AHTD).</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:purpose> The Northwest Arkansas Regional Planning Commission, the Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies, the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville, or Arkansas Geographic Information Office does not accept liability for any damages or misrepresentation caused by inaccuracies in the data or as a result of changes to the data caused by system transfers or other transformations or conversions, nor is there responsibility assumed to maintain the data in any manner or form.  This data has been developed from the best available sources. Although efforts have been made to ensure that the data is accurate and reliable, errors and variable conditions originating from physical sources used to develop the data may be reflected in the data supplied. Users must be aware of these conditions and bear responsibility for the appropriate use of the information with respect to possible errors, scale, resolution, rectification, positional accuracy, development methodology, time period, environmental and climatic conditions and other circumstances specific to this data. The user is responsible for understanding the accuracy limitations of the data provided herein. The burden for determining fitness for use lies entirely with the user.  The user should refer to the accompanying metadata notes for a description of the data and data development procedures.  Although this data has been processed successfully on computers at the Northwest Arkansas Regional Planning Commission, the Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies, the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville, and Arkansas Geographic Information Office, no guarantee, expressed or implied, is made by any of these entities regarding the use of these data on any other system, nor does the act of distribution constitute or imply any such warranty. Assessment</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:nameOfMeasure>                <gmd:measureDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString/>                </gmd:measureDescription>                <gmd:evaluationMethodDescription/>                <gmd:result>                   <gmd:DQ_QuantitativeResult>                      <gmd:valueUnit>                         <gml:BaseUnit gml:id="d3534e420">                            <gml:identifier codeSpace="local">meters</gml:identifier>                            <gml:unitsSystem xlink:href="http://www.bipm.org/en/si/"/>                         </gml:BaseUnit>                      </gmd:valueUnit>                      <gmd:value>                         <gco:Record>2</gco:Record>                      </gmd:value>                   </gmd:DQ_QuantitativeResult>                </gmd:result>             </gmd:DQ_QuantitativeAttributeAccuracy>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:lineage>             <gmd:LI_Lineage>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>Ground Control Point Acquisition Description Survey Control. The work described under this section of the specifications consists of ground control surveys and analytical aerotriangulation, required for photogrammetric mapping of the entire controlled area of the survey consisting of one thousand eight hundred thirty two +/- (1832) square miles. GPS Control Data. LandAir Mapping Inc. mobilized a technical team under the supervision of a registered land surveyor, to capture pertinent information in accordance with the project design. LandAir Mapping Inc. tied to existing NGS control monuments (FAYETTEVILLE_PID_GG0952, ROGERS_PID_GG0921 and XNA_PID_AI2976) to establish a minimum of 135 Ground Control Points (GCP). All ground control was based on Arkansas State Plane Coordinate System, NAD 83. All ground control surveys were performed by a professional land surveyor. Average PDOP for all GPS collection was 4 with no level being greater than 6.b. The Ground Control Network was established on Public R-O-W or NWARPC partners owned property or private property with written permission. Analytical Aerotriangulation. Fully Digital Analytical Aerial Triangulation was accomplished using first order softcopy stereo instruments and industry standard fully analytical block adjustment software. A minimum of nine pass points per frame, with the exception of end frames of the flight lines, which carried six pass points. LandAir Mapping Inc. used ZI Imaging softcopy system for AT and orthorectification for this project. Control Deliverables. The Contractor, LandAir Mapping Inc., delivered the following control related items to the NWARPC:1. All hard and soft copy control survey data for ground GPS control including drawings and/or annotated photographs of sufficient detail to identify each point, and GPS adjustment reports including point covariance matrices2. The full analytical aerotriangulation report.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime gco:nilReason="unknown"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>LIDAR Scope. The work described under this section of the specifications consists of Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) for remote ground sensing of the entire mapping area consisting of one thousand eight hundred thirty two +/- (1832) square miles. Existing Data. There was not existing LIDAR data for this project area. Flight Plan. A flight plan showing the flight lines, flight line spacing, and aircraft was submitted and pre-approved before work could begin. There was a 14-ft average point spacing for a maximum allowable point spacing of 5 meters to achieve a 1.2ft accuracy at 95 % (NSSDA) according to FEMA Appendix A: Guidance for Aerial Mapping and Surveying. The following is a summary of LIDAR mission settings for this project: Laser Frequency -- 25 KHzHeight of Flight Above Mean Terrain -- 3.7 KmAircraft speed -- 120 MPHSwath of Flight -- 2.7 KmFlight line Spacing -- 15% of swath width Field of View -- 40 Degrees Scanning rate -- 14 HzAverage Point Spacing -- 14 ft (4.2m)LandAir Mapping, Inc. verified that these mission parameters meet the stated FEMA guidelines. Flight line length did not exceed 20 miles to avoid IMU "drift" which causes IMU sensors to record inaccurate attitude data. The contractor entered the project constraints into aircraft navigation software offering differentially corrected navigation system allowing the pilot to be within a few meters of the flight line without variances due to GPS wandering.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime gco:nilReason="unknown"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>Ground Control. In addition to GPS ground control for base stations, photogrammetric control, and existing control monuments, the contractor established control points for internal quality assurance and quality control (QA/QC).All newly established horizontal and vertical controls were tied and adjusted to the appropriate horizontal and vertical coordinate systems, i.e. UTM zone 15 and State Plane NAD83.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime gco:nilReason="unknown"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>LIDAR System Cabration. Calibration of the LIDAR system was performed to insure vertical and horizontal accuracies including graphical and analytical computations. The contractor initially calibrated the system by conducting calibration flights, which were flown over a large building with roof corners that have been previously surveyed with GPS and conventional methods. This graphically based process uses several passes made over the building at different angles and heights to insure the proper correction factors are entered into the processing software for roll, pitch and heading of the plane. The contractor performed calibration flights before and after project to insure that the highest possible accuracies were obtained. For the second calibration approach the Contractor compared relative elevations and location of LIDAR shots of overlapping flight lines. This automated analytical procedure used Least Squares technique on a bare earth terrain with gentle slopes. If the initial calibration was successful, the aircraft attitude results produced by this procedure are insignificant (close to zero); otherwise, the initial calibration approach would have been revisited and further adjustments made. LIDAR Data Collection. The LIDAR project was conducted from a twin-engine aircraft flying a regular pattern over the survey area. GPS accuracy was critical to the overall data accuracy, and the contractor used a minimum of two GPS ground receivers to better determine the aircraft trajectory. Contractors GPS processing software utilized multiple base receivers to compute GPS positions more accurately. Prior to the flight, two ground-based GPS units were set up at control points in the survey area, and tied to the local HARN network. The control was selected so that no one baseline for the ground to the plane exceeded 20 Miles. The contractors field operation crew included a LIDAR specialist, a professional Land Surveyor, and a Certified Photogrammetrist. Average PDOP for all GPS collection was 4 with no level being greater than 6.Data Processing. The contractor used a tiling scheme consistent with the USGS National DOQQ Program and utilized a minimum buffer of 100 feet beyond boundaries. Point file tile size did not exceed 600 Mb, uncompressed.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime gco:nilReason="unknown"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>LIDAR Mapping Product Preparation. The contractors field survey team conducted a minimum of ten, five-hundred foot transects (approximately one per fifty sq. miles) utilizing GPS surveying methods to support their (the contractors) internal QA/QC process. Transects were randomly located within and representative of the various land use or land covers throughout the project areas. Prior to vegetation removal, a data analysis was performed to check LIDAR data versus ground control elevations. The Contactors initial step was to build a DEM of the LIDAR overlaps within the study area and regularly check the cross sections of overlapping LIDAR swaths to ensure compatibility and integrity of the elevation data. A least squares computer program was used to determine any unnoticed positional discrepancies between swaths. LandAir Mapping Inc. used a combination of aerial photos, field verification data, and cross sections combined with ground control data throughout the project area to ensure the best quality of the product. After automated vegetation removal, mapping technicians manually removed remaining outliers. 3D data viewing and contouring combined with overlaid digital imagery was used to complete the manual filtering process. The Contractors Quality Control specialists verified the integrity of the mapping technician's product and necessary corrections were made, if necessary. DTM Collection. Breaklines and mass points were collected as needed to supplement LIDAR point elevation data. If said breaklines and mass points were derived from stereo models based on the AT results of the AHTD images, it is expected that they WOULD NOT meet NSSDA and FEMA guidelines for the development of 2ft contours, but they meet NSSDA requirements for 5ft contours. Breaklines collected to supplement LIDAR point elevations were of sufficient quality to support digital orthorectification as defined in herein.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime gco:nilReason="unknown"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>Accuracies.DEM:1.36 feet vertical accuracy (NSSDA - 95% confidence level)Deliverables. The contractor delivered the following LIDAR products to the NWARPC:I. General1. LIDAR Point cloud and DEM in x,y,z format2. LIDAR raw data including x,y,z and intensity values for all returns3. Bare-earth mass point data4. Ground control data5. DEM (40ft rectangular grid used in orthorectifying process)6. DEM (25ft rectangular grid)II. Reports1. Flight Report2. Ground Control Report3. System Calibration Report4. Data Processing Procedure Report5. PDOP Report and/or Chart6. LIDAR System Data Report</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime gco:nilReason="unknown"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>             </gmd:LI_Lineage>          </gmd:lineage>       </gmd:DQ_DataQuality>    </gmd:dataQualityInfo>    <gmd:metadataConstraints>       <gmd:MD_LegalConstraints>
